"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." The Congress finds a crisis in writing skills in schools and workplaces, with nearly 1/3 of high school graduates not ready for college-level English composition. Deficiencies in writing skills cost the private sector billions annually. The National Writing Project is the only national program addressing this issue since 1973. The National Writing Project is a collaborative university-school program that has shown significant gains in student writing performance and effective classroom practices. It serves as a model for improving teaching in various subjects and benefits over 135,000 teachers annually in all 50 states and other territories. The National Writing Project, a successful university-school program, aims to expand its network nationwide, maintain high-quality sites, share effective teaching practices, and coordinate activities under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. The National Writing Project aims to expand its network nationwide and maintain high-quality sites under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. The Secretary is authorized to award a grant to the National Writing Project to improve the teaching of writing in classrooms through teacher training programs. The grantee will establish and operate teacher training programs for effective writing instruction, with funds from the Secretary covering the Federal share of costs. Grantees must meet specified conditions and standards for compliance. Teacher training programs will be conducted during the school year. Teacher training programs authorized in subsection (a) will be conducted year-round, train teachers from kindergarten to college, select teachers for a National Writing Project network, and encourage teachers from all disciplines to participate. The Federal share covers 50% of the costs for these programs. The Federal share of teacher training program costs is 50%, with a maximum limit of $150,000 for one contractor or $300,000 for a statewide program. The Secretary can waive this requirement based on financial need, as determined by the National Advisory Board established by the National Writing Project. The National Writing Project will establish a National Advisory Board composed of national educational leaders, writing experts, and other necessary individuals. The Board's duties include advising on student writing issues, reviewing programs, and supporting the project's development. The Secretary will conduct an independent evaluation of teacher training programs under the National Writing Project, specifying funds spent on administrative costs. A funding limitation of $150,000 for fiscal year 2008 and subsequent years will be reserved from the total appropriation. The National Writing Project will establish a Review Board to evaluate applications for funding assistance, consisting of research leaders in writing and other necessary individuals. The Board will recommend applications for funding by the National Writing Project. The National Writing Project will establish a Review Board to evaluate applications for funding assistance and recommend applications for funding by the National Writing Project. $30,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2008, with additional funding for the following 5 years.
